user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_add_to_fd_set_:
```c
int
MHD_add_to_fd_set_ (MHD_socket fd,
                    fd_set *set,
                    MHD_socket *max_fd,
                    int fd_setsize)
{
  if ( (NULL == set) ||
       (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET == fd) )
    return 0;

#ifndef HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE
  (void) fd_setsize;  /* Mute compiler warning */
  fd_setsize = (int) FD_SETSIZE; /* Help compiler to optimise */
#endif /* ! HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE */

  if (! MHD_SCKT_FD_FITS_FDSET_SETSIZE_ (fd,
                                         set,
                                         fd_setsize))
    return 0;
  MHD_SCKT_ADD_FD_TO_FDSET_SETSIZE_ (fd,
                                     set,
                                     fd_setsize);
  if ( (NULL != max_fd) &&
       ( (fd > *max_fd) ||
         (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET == *max_fd) ) )
    *max_fd = fd;
  return ! 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_add_to_fd_set_:
#define MHD_SCKT_FD_FITS_FDSET_SETSIZE_(fd, pset, setsize) ((fd)<((MHD_socket)(setsize)))
...
#define MHD_SCKT_ADD_FD_TO_FDSET_SETSIZE_(fd, pset, setsize) FD_SET((fd),(pset))
...
#define MHD_INVALID_SOCKET (-1)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no uses of memcmp or any string-comparison operations in the provided code. The function only performs pointer/null checks, integer comparisons, and FD_SET-related macros:
- No call to memcmp is present in MHD_add_to_fd_set_.
- There are no char* or null-terminated string variables being compared anywhere in the fragment.
- The MHD_SCKT_FD_FITS_FDSET_SETSIZE_ macro is an integer comparison ((fd) < (setsize)).
- The MHD_SCKT_ADD_FD_TO_FDSET_SETSIZE_ macro expands to FD_SET((fd),(pset)), which is a file-descriptor set operation, not a string compare.
- MHD_INVALID_SOCKET is an integer constant (-1); comparisons against it are integer comparisons.
Given the absence of memcmp calls or string operands, there are no fragments that need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 in the provided code. If memcmp were used in other included or external macros/headers not shown here, those locations would need review, but nothing in the supplied code invokes or hides memcmp.
